entries.title: Strawberry Perl 5.14.2 has a preview release
entries.text: Finally!

entries.title: Perl Weekly reaches 2000 subscribers
entries.text: Yes, that's about this newsletter. And since then its is up to 2068. A little more promotion and we get to 10,000 :-)

entries.title: What is the Marpa algorithm?
entries.text: We already saw a few articles by Jeffrey Kegler about his Marpa module. In this article he explains the theory and the algorithm behind it.

entries.title: Promoting Perl's Features versus Benefits
entries.text: chromatic shows a couple of examples to explain what the listener will benefit by using Perl. It's an art though. Sometimes you need to emphasize the features and show the benefits in other, more subtle ways.

entries.title: What's actually installed in that perl library?
entries.text: Tim Bunce (you know, the guy who wrote DBI), describes his solution when his company wanted to move from a very old Perl to a new one. The primary problem being the fact that they did not have proper configuration management earlier.

entries.title: New & Improved: MooseX::Role::BuildInstanceOf
entries.text: Written by Yanick Champoux (yanick), the pollinator agent.

entries.title: Dist::Zilla, Pod::Weaver and bin
entries.text: Flavio Poletti fights Dist::Zilla and Pod::Weaver in public. And wins! There is a certain value when someone describes the path to the solution and not only the solution. That helps people build accept that they are not expected to come up with a solution out of the blue. It also helps people learning the fine art of problem solving.

entries.title: CPAN dependencies are more fun to manage than ever
entries.text: Tatsuhiko Miyagawa continues to steal ideas from Ruby. This time he is proposing cpanfile - a way to declare and manage CPAN dependencies in an application.

entries.title: LPW2011 Talk Slides
entries.text: Paul Evans (LeoNerd) links to his 'A Protocol for Protocols' and 'Tickit' talk slides.

entries.title: Mojocast #4: Stash, Flash, and Sessions
entries.text: Glen Hinkle (tempire) releases the 4th episode of the screencasts about Mojolicious.

entries.title: Time spent waiting for tests you know will pass is time wasted
entries.text: Here, the anti-thesis. Every talks about how important testing is and how important running the tests is and then here comes Fred Moyer (Phred) and explains why is that a waste of time. The comments have a solution. Binary distributions. So, what do you say?

entries.title: Test::DatabaseRow 2
entries.text: Test::DatabaseRow has been part of my testing training for many years now but I always had a bit of a strange feeling as it only handled one single row. Now Mark Fowler has refactored and upgraded the module and among other things it can now test multiple rows. Here he explains some of his decisions.

entries.title: Rakudo: this wee's release, and the next Rakudo Star
entries.text: A few days ago version #46 of Rakudo came out and in this article Jonathan Worthington describes what is in the new version: 'Big Integer Support', 'Protoregexes with LTM', 'CATCH improvements', 'Improved MAIN argument parsing', '6model REPR API 2' just to copy the titles. Detailed explanation in the blog post.

entries.title: How to teach 'Modern' Perl?
entries.text: People have strong opinions on what Modern Perl means but they don't always work out of the box and sometimes it isn't a good thing to teach those practices first. In this article I was trying to discuss some of the issues I see.

entries.title: London Perl Workshop 2011, Reflection, part two
entries.text: Mark Keating (MDK), the organizer of the London Perl Workshop, looks back at this years event.

entries.title: Padre 0.92, the release!
entries.text: Peter Lavender, the release manager if Padre report the new version. Installable from CPAN. This is the first version that requires Wx::Scintilla. Padre also has real-time VCS built in now.

entries.title: Stackoverflow perl report
entries.text: Miguel Prz (niceperl) continues with his new tradition and lists the 10 most popular Perl related questions on StackOverflow. I hope people in the Perl community take notice and start following the Perl tag on SO.
